This snow pit was dug on a SE aspect where the snow has received a lot of solar effect. The snowpack is almost at isothermal conditions, with some very wet heavy snow in the top 30cm. No faceting or depth hoar was observed through the entirety of this pit.

I did not dig all the war to the ground because a storm was moving in but i discovered that the new snow was still bonding well and several ice layers were lurking 30cm below the surface. The snowpack was presenting signed of stability. Storm slab and sluffs would be my greatest concern with the new snow and temperature flux.

This pit displayed some instability within the top 30cm with the new snow load sliding on a ice layer. I would be cautious of storm slabs and big sluffs in steep terrain and ring temperatures.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Recent activity on similar slopes; Ski tracks on slope

I dug this pit after a fresh snow fall of 4-7inches. The snow fell wet and bonded well with the preexisting surface. No major signs of instability were recognizable. A few layers of ice are present within the top 60 cm of the snowpack, however they were not reactive to any stability tests. The structure of the snow pack seems strong and the strength is relatively good.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: The cold temperatures at night have been just enough to keep the higher altitude snowpack locked up. Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Rain has saturated through the entire snowpack again, slush layer on top of where the last rain/freeze event ended. Didn't observe any natural activity on the open slopes, but sliding was observed where the pack was thinner (trees, open road cuts, rock face edges). Snowpack looked similar on all aspects.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Tracking Feb21st CR/SH/FC

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: I dug this snow pit on the north face of Mount Yeckel outside of Aspen Colorado. My results found the top meter of snow to consist mostly of melt form grains with 10cm of Decomposing precipitation particles sitting on top from the last storm of 03/03 - 03/6. The Snow pack is generally right side up with the lower half being very think and cohesive with no active weak layers. The temperature is gradually working its way to become isothermal in the lower half of the snowpack. No stability tests were conducted and no signs of instability were observed. The snow made great turns and felt very supportable while skiing on it.
HS = 320 cm

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Ilmatieteenlaitoksen stressitesti 25 cm syvyydestä, 3 laatikko/1,5 kg. Vesiarvotesti 1 putki 25 cm/66. Tuulenpakkaamaan tuiskulunta, jonka alla heikko uuden lumen kerros. Lohkesi ja irtosi lapioitaessa helposti. Hangen kantavuus vaihtelee edelleen suuresti lyhyelläkin välimatkalla.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown of skier triggered slide on 3/8/2017. Obvious hard wind slab from downslope winds resting in softer snow. Bed surface was at 315cm. What was remarkable was the width of this slide. It was 250-300 feet wide and ran maybe 350 feet slope distance. The weak layer was primarily decomposing stellars, but they may have gotten just a touch faceted. I couldn't tell. Even on such a relatively hot day today, as the sun disappeared behind Mt. Superior, the temps started dropping quickly. I wouldn't be surprising if new snow from the Sunday/Monday storm had just a touch of diurnal recrystallization.
Investigate mid-Feb pwl

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This pit is representative of all three pits dug today on S, NE, and N aspects in Canyon Creek, Skookoleel Creek and Lakalaho/Skookoleel Ridge areas. Approximately 70 inches of snow accumulated over the past 8 days.

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking; Snowmobile tracks on slope; We snowmobiled slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Increasing windloading throughout the day, thick deposits already early on. Surface hoar revealed to S, SE, resulting in release and remote release of Small to medium avalanches.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Shovel tilt test lead to easy failures within new snow. No propagation. Snow pit dug down to knife hardness rain crust layer. Deep tap tests led to no failures at crust layer.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This snowpack displays that the top 10 or so cm of snow is sitting onto of a melt freeze layer collapsing 140cm down on a persistent grain layer. From 140cm down the snow pack is much stronger comprised of mostly melt form grains with the temperature working its way to isothermal conditions.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Triggered 3-4 large, rumbling collapses as we ascended, prompting this pit. One person's skin track already ascended. We had two large collapses while breaking trail, then had two while on the already established skin track. Instability isolated to nearby similar terrain, but significant.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, widespread; Cracking; Recent activity on different slopes
Snowmobile tracks on slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: I wanted to explore and see what was happening within the snow pack on the souther aspects. I discovered less hight of snow depth over all, a melt freeze crust and a semi cohesive grain type throughout the snow pack. The temp profile indicates that possible isothermal temps are in the future. Would not recommend yet for skiing.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on similar slopes

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: I took a tour up Jim's creek with the intention of reckoning some new ski lines on a south facing aspect when I stumbled across a nice protected north facing sparkly open slope, I decided to dig here and investigate. The snow was still fresh from the last snow fall with some wind effect present. The snow felt fresh and right side up in the first 30cm. No real widespread crusts were present, nevertheless, my main concern would be triggering the wind slab about 40cm down. The lower half of the snow pack seemed very stable and couldn't get anything to propagate.

Quick data pit

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope
Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Prior pit to this lower on slope, at top of steeper meadow had ECTNs at storm interfaces, no propagation, or obvious SH layers. Weak layer was not obvious until CT, and then ECTP 13 was a bit of a surprise. Shorter PST cut (15/100) was result of placing slab from previous test on top of the second PST, essentially doubling the load.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Cold, clear, calm day with W winds only noticeable at the ridge top of Andacite Peak. Our CT and TT observations revealed sudden planar failures at 16cm and 32 cm, and an anomalous layer between 62-70cm that was harder than the surrounding layers. All in all, the avalanche danger was considered low, as no significant whumping, cracking, or natural avalanches of any consequence were recognized.
1 group member experienced collapsing - Efforts to repeat were unsuccessful. 3 very small (less than 1.5 meters) loose dry point releases were observed below cornice feature.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Observations made SE of Andesite Peak, below ridge line. Evidence of recent small natural Loose Snow Avalanche below cornice located above and to the Northwest of Observation site. One member of party noted localized collapse under skis as we skinned uphill to the site, below treeline.

Pit was dug W/SW facing under Andesite Ridge - did not take a formal directional heading. Mostly out of wind exposure, however, after summiting Andesite, wind exposure from the W was noticeable w/ a guess of wind speed around ~20 mph. Did not notice any snow movement due to wind.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Cool weather supporting previous trends.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Ser ut som om siste døgns mildværsgrense har gått på ca. 600 moh, og det har frosset på i overflaten etter temperaturfall. Over 600 moh er det i stor grad fokksnø som preger terrenget. Bærer en skiløper noen steder, mens det andre steder bryter gjennom.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Had winds from several directions over the last 3 days, windslabs in the steeps are of concern. Observed good bonding of the new storm snow to the rain layers. The lower 120cm of the snowpack is still high water content from the rain last week.
